text: <!channel> i am installing some bookshelves at home… have some nice birch plywood that i want to finish with something natural looking that will bring out the grain and make the color a little richer. any recommendations on polyurethane vs varnish vs shellac? def don’t want something i need to re-apply every year. one and done.
the things you mentioned are actually in order of easy -> difficult to use
Anything you use will bring out the grain. I'm not sure on if one will bring it out more than others
The mantra in finishing is to always test it out on a hidden or scrap piece
I like to use oils, like Danish oil or Watco. This is probably closest to "varnish". I've also had good luck with water-based poly (Minwax Polycrylic)
cool. never done this before - what makes one more difficult to use than another?
shellac is difficult because it takes greater care in applying (it dries super quick, so keeping a wet edge is harder). It also hardens in the jar faster than other kinds
gotcha
thanks for the info!

also take note of drying time vs curing time. Usually a coat will take several minutes to several hours to dry (enough for light handling), but several hours to several days to fully cure (finish off-gassing, surface hardens). Using your shelf when it's dried but not cured could result in an uneven texture, or even oil seeping into the book
and of course, applying multiple coats is almost always a good thing. it's usually recommended to sand lightly between coats with ≥200 grit paper
oooh very good to know. as far as off-gassing goes… best to just leave it outside to cure i suppose?
outside or in a room with a window open and a fan going.
outside you might have to worry about falling leaves, bird poop, etc
and i would want to let it dry but not cure between coats?
it depends, but generally no. re-coating can usually happen once its' dry enough to handle
If you are using varnish or shellac you may also have to buff at a specific time. I know that when applying Tung oil you need to buff ~5 minutes after brushing it on
These details would be covered in the instructions on the side of the can though :)
sweet
thanks spencer!!
related reading: <http://www.popularwoodworking.com/techniques/finishing>

attachments.title: Woodworking Finishing
attachments.text: Make your woodworking projects shine with our expert wood finishing techniques. Get tips on how to finish wood. Finish furniture like a true master.

hah, nice
If your finish doesn't bring out the grain enough you could look into "grain painting" <http://www.workbenchdiary.com/2014/09/tool-chest-paint-day-1.html>
oh hell no
people do that for marble too
